org.chronos.chronodb.internal.api.index

Interface ChronoIndexDocument

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ChronoIndexDocumentImpl

    public interface ChronoIndexDocument
    A ChronoIndexDocument is an abstraction across all indexing backends.

    This interface is essentially just a (largely immutable) collection of primitive values:

    • Document ID (immutable): getDocumentId()
    • Branch Name (immutable): getBranch()
    • Keyspace Name (immutable): getKeyspace()
    • Key (immutable): getKey()
    • Index Name (immutable): getIndexName()
    • Indexed Value (immutable): getIndexedValue()
    • "Valid From" timestamp (immutable): getValidFromTimestamp()
    • "Valid To" timestamp (mutable): getValidToTimestamp(), setValidToTimestamp(long)

    Collectively, these properties define a single entry in an index. The entry contains all properties required for a ChronoIdentifier, alongside the index name to which it belongs, and the value that was retrieved by the indexer for the object in question. In order to allow for temporal indexing, a "valid from" and "valid to" timestamp are used. An index document can only be considered for a transaction if:

    • getValidFromTimestamp() <= ChronoDBTransaction.getTimestamp()
    • ChronoDBTransaction.getTimestamp() < getValidToTimestamp()

    The general idea behind this validity range is that when a value of a key is changed, the "valid to" timestamp of the currently valid index document is set to the transaction timestamp, and a new index document is spawned for the new value, starting with "valid from" at the transaction timestamp.

    This class has the following implicit invariants:

    • The "valid from" timestamp must always be strictly smaller than "valid to".
    • The "valid to" timestamp of a document that is newly created is set to Long.MAX_VALUE.
    • The "valid to" timestamp may be changed, but it may only be decreased, never increased.
    • The "valid to" timestamp may not be decreased to a value lower than or equal to the "now" timestamp of the branch.

    Instances of this class are not to be created by clients; they are created internally by the indexing API (usually by an DocumentBasedIndexManagerBackend) and should never be exposed to the public API.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.String getBranch()
      Returns the name of the branch in which the value represented by this document was indexed (immutable property).
      java.lang.String getDocumentId()
      Returns the universally unique id of this document (immutable property).
      java.lang.Object getIndexedValue()
      Returns the indexed value represented by this document (immutable property).
      java.lang.String getIndexName()
      Returns the name of the index to which this document belongs (immutable property).
      java.lang.String getKey()
      Returns the key that references the indexed value represented by this document (immutable property).
      java.lang.String getKeyspace()
      Returns the name of the keyspace in which the value represented by this document was indexed (immutable property).
      long getValidFromTimestamp()
      Returns the "valid from" timestamp.
      long getValidToTimestamp()
      Returns the "valid to" timestamp (mutable property).
      void setValidToTimestamp(long validTo)
      Sets the "valid to" timestamp to the given value.

    • Method Detail

      • getDocumentId

        java.lang.String getDocumentId()
        Returns the universally unique id of this document (immutable property).
        Returns:
        The UUID of this document as a string. Never null.

      • getIndexName

        java.lang.String getIndexName()
        Returns the name of the index to which this document belongs (immutable property).
        Returns:
        The index name. Never null.

      • getBranch

        java.lang.String getBranch()
        Returns the name of the branch in which the value represented by this document was indexed (immutable property).
        Returns:
        The branch name. Never null.

      • getKeyspace

        java.lang.String getKeyspace()
        Returns the name of the keyspace in which the value represented by this document was indexed (immutable property).
        Returns:
        The keyspace name. Never null.

      • getKey

        java.lang.String getKey()
        Returns the key that references the indexed value represented by this document (immutable property).
        Returns:
        The key. Never null.

      • getIndexedValue

        java.lang.Object getIndexedValue()
        Returns the indexed value represented by this document (immutable property).
        Returns:
        The indexed value. Never null.

      • getValidFromTimestamp

        long getValidFromTimestamp()
        Returns the "valid from" timestamp. This corresponds to the timestamp at which this document was written (immutable property).

        Any transaction which has "valid from <= timestamp < valid to" may read and must consider this document for index queries.

        Returns:
        The "valid from" timestamp. Never negative.

      • getValidToTimestamp

        long getValidToTimestamp()
        Returns the "valid to" timestamp (mutable property).

        Initially, this will be set to Long.MAX_VALUE until a new value is assigned to the key, in which case this value is decremented to indicate the termination of the validity interval.

        Any transaction which has "valid from <= timestamp < valid to" may read and must consider this document for index queries.

        Returns:
        The "valid to" timestamp.

      • setValidToTimestamp

        void setValidToTimestamp(long validTo)
        Sets the "valid to" timestamp to the given value.

        Note that the "valid to" timestamp may only be decremented, but never incremented. It must never be decremented to a value lower than the "now" timestamp of the current branch. It must also never be lower than or equal to the "valid from" timestamp.

        Any transaction which has "valid from <= timestamp < valid to" may read and must consider this document for index queries.

        Parameters:
        validTo - The new "valid to" value. Subject to the constraints explained above. Must not be negative.
